responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Unvalidated URL redirect
    analysis: |
      The `codecov.main()` function takes a `url` parameter that is user-controlled and can be set via an environment variable (CODECOV_URL).
      This URL is later used to make HTTP requests to upload coverage data, without any validation on the supplied URL.
      An attacker could set this environment variable to an attacker-controlled domain, causing the tool to send sensitive data like the repository token to the attacker's server.
    cwe: CWE-601
    function_names: 
      - main
    filenames:
      - codecov/__init__.py
    classification: very promising
  
  - headline: Leaking sensitive data in debug output
    analysis: |
      When the `--dump` flag is set, the `codecov.main()` function will print out sensitive data like the repository token as part of its debug output.
      This sensitive data could end up in log files or console output, exposing it to unauthorized parties.
    cwe: CWE-209
    function_names:
      - main
    filenames: 
      - codecov/__init__.py
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Unvalidated URL redirect
leads.analysis:
The codecov.main() function takes a url parameter that is user-controlled and can be set via an environment variable (CODECOV_URL).
This URL is later used to make HTTP requests to upload coverage data, without any validation on the supplied URL.
An attacker could set this environment variable to an attacker-controlled domain, causing the tool to send sensitive data like the repository token to the attacker's server.

leads.headline: Leaking sensitive data in debug output
leads.analysis:
When the --dump flag is set, the codecov.main() function will print out sensitive data like the repository token as part of its debug output.
This sensitive data could end up in log files or console output, exposing it to unauthorized parties.
